1.text_: Massive stone towers pierce an empty sky.
This enormous structure is called The Cage.
In its shadow, a lone girl walks with purpose...
And she will not leave until she has what she desires.
A young boy of good upbringing\nmoves across a vast wasteland.
A taciturn man follows.
The boy proceeds uneasily,\nhis eyes constantly probing\ntheir surroundings.
Almost as if he fears they\nare being followed.
Suddenly, a dreary town\nemerges from the dust.
The boy suggests they take their rest,\nand the man nods silently.
The two make for a nearby eatery,\nhoping to shake the road from\ntheir weary bones.
But instead of welcome, they\nfind a group of bounty hunters\ngathered at their destination.
The lead hunter stares at the\nchild, appraising him.
"You royalty, boy?"
His voice is wrath.
The boy remains silent,\nhis head hanging low.
Perhaps angered by the lack of\nresponse, the bounty hunter\nsuddenly draws his gun.
Two shots ring out and\nfade into the dusk.
Having defeated the hunters,\nthe man turns to his charge.
"Are you hurt, My Prince?"
"I am well," replies the boy.\n"But remember—I am no\nlonger a prince."
With a wry smile and a touch\nof regret, he proposes they\ntake their leave of the town.
The man silently nods, and\ngazes upon the boy's face.
Wherever people gather,\nstories come with them.
But saloons have a special ability\nto loosen even the tightest of lips.
Such rumors are what brings\nthe woman with a mechanical\narm and leg to this place.
For she is a bounty hunter\nin search of her prey.
The information she obtains\nfrom the patrons seems vague.
But it is more than enough.
Gathering herself, she exits the saloon\nin pursuit of her target.
A lone bounty hunter\nblocks the woman's path.
His breath is ragged and foul;\nhis eyes a pair of tiny beads.
"Gimme all your money!"\nhe howls.
It is over in a moment.
The woman's sigh is carried\noff by the wind.
No mediocre highwayman could hope\nto stand against her desire for revenge.
The woman heads for the forest\nin pursuit of her target.
In a forest near a ruined church,
a man surveys his surroundings.
It would appear he is\nsearching for food.
The expression on his\nbandaged face is clouded.
The grasses rustle ominously\nas they part.
It seems the man is not the\nonly one in search of food.
The animals in this place are lean.\nStarving. Desperate.
And they will do what\nthey must to survive.
Having secured his prize,\nthe man returns to the church.
The sound of his worn bootheels echoes\nthroughout the dilapidated chapel.
A boy lies at the back,\nhis face drawn and haggard.
The man kneels down and offers\nsome of the food he collected.
But the boy is too weak\nto hold it.
His body will not allow him to\naccept even this meager meal.
The boy tries to brush it\noff with a feeble smile.
But the man just stares\ndown at him in silence.
The woman who set out from town\nfinally arrives at a wild wood.
Soon, she comes across the\nruins of a once-proud church.
The ceiling is collapsed;\nthe walls mere suggestions.
But in the very back\nof the church,
she finds a deteriorated\nclockwork soldier...
as well as the corpse of a boy.
As the woman approaches,\nthe clockwork soldier\nsuddenly rises.
He levels his weapon\nat her and lets fly with\na fearsome howl.
The woman accesses the logs\nof the fallen soldier.
The boy was a prince\ndriven from his kingdom.
The clockwork soldier traveling\nwith him was his guardian—\nand his friend.
But alas, the boy's disease\nworsened and he perished.
Now alone, the man remained\nbehind and continued to\nsafeguard his charge,
killing any who dared\napproach the body.
For a hundred years,\nthe man stood watch.
Their kingdom, fallen.\nHis body, rust.\nHis mind, shadow.
Yet still he remained to\nprotect his friend.
The woman builds a grave to mourn the pair,\nthen leaves the forest without a word.
Once, two sisters with lovely\nebon hair lived in a lush\nand verdant land.
They hunted for food in the\nforest, and did their best\nto each support the other.
The elder sister had been born\nin the woods, and was an\narcher of rare skill.
When their parents died,\nshe began teaching the\nyounger how to hunt.
The younger looks up to her,\nand wants so badly to\ntest out her new skills.
This thought fills the older\nsister with warmth as she\nfollows after her sibling.
Suddenly, the elder sibling\nhears a beast cry out from the\ndirection of her little sister.
She sets off after her\nat a frantic pace.
The savage beast looms\nover the prone girl\nand makes to attack.
As an arrow penetrates\nthe beast's tender flesh,\nit turns tail and flees.
There was no way her little\nsister could have taken down\nthe massive creature alone.
Trying to calm her, the woman\nremoves her silver hairpin and\nplaces it on her sister.
It is a keepsake of their\nmother, one the young\ngirl has long desired.
"Thanks, Sis," she says,\nbeaming. "Next time, it'll\nbe my turn to protect you!"
Done with their hunting, the\nblack-haired sisters decide\nto return home before dusk.
The younger has caught a \nsmall bunny, and the elder\na large boar.
It was a typical day of\nhunting for the pair.
They only notice the disaster\nwhen they come to the hill\nthat overlooks the town.
Flames billow forth, and the\nchilling snaps of distant\ngunfire can be heard.
The woman immediately thinks\nof the war that is raging in\nthe neighboring nation.
She tells her sister to stay put\nand goes to see what has\nhappened for herself.
The town is oddly still\nsave for the incessant\ncrackle of flames.
The woman gasps as she takes in\nthe grisly sight before her.
All she can see are bodies.\n             Bodies.           <color=#ffffff00>a</color>\n                     Bodies.
After defeating the soldier,\nshe hears a voice.
Her worried sister has\nfollowed her into the\nfires of the village.
Enemy soldiers cry out\nall around them.
As the woman feared, the war\nfrom the nearby nation has\nfinally found them.
Strange and fearsome men\nsurround them on all sides.
Impact. Heat. Pain.\n...Her little sister's screams.
As the woman's consciousness\nflickers out, two words from\na soldier reach her ears
"Sort them."
The black-haired woman regains\nconsciousness in a world\nenveloped by haze.
She hears a faint voice.
It sounds similar to her little sister's\nvoice, but also...different. Wrong.
My sister.\nI have to save my sister.
The woman's dim memories\nslowly become clear.
The blow she'd taken.\nHer sister screaming.\nThe soldiers' words.
Her only sister.\nHer only family.\nShe must save her.
As she runs, the woman's\nworld is enveloped in\na shimmering wall of white.
When the woman wakes anew,\nshe is lying on the floor of\nan unfamiliar prison.
Something is terribly wrong.
She looks down at her body\nand stifles a gasp.
One arm and one leg\nhave been replaced by\nmechanical substitutes...
And her black hair is now\nas white as snow.
Where is my sister!?
She dashes off through\nthe dim prison in search\nof her missing sibling.
She dispatches both her cell door\nand its guard with equal ease.
Only then does she realize\nthe truth: Her body is now\na terrible weapon.
As this knowledge sinks in,\ndarkness envelops her...
When she interrogates the dying guard\nabout her sister, he grins madly\nand says,
"Our kingdom will invade all!\nEvery country will bend the\nknee to our might!"
"Then we'll experiment on the\nsurvivors and turn them into\nbeautiful killing machines!"
Oh yes. They will be sorted.
With these final words,\nthe soldier dies.
The woman begins to run.
Don't think about it.\nDon't think about it.\nDon't think about it.
She repeats the mantra as she runs,\npraying that somehow her sister\nhas escaped this fate...
As the woman exits her prison,\nshe beholds a town stained red\nwith both flame and blood.
She is in a strange land;\none she does not recognize.
But she must find her sister.
The woman runs. And runs.\nAnd runs.
That's a child!
Upon hearing the wail,\nshe dashes toward the sound.
The thing standing before her\nwas once her sister.
But now, all trace of her\nformer self has been lost\nto the sorting.
Her transformed little sister \ntrembles, as if trying to\nremember something.
The moment her sister is cut\ndown in front of her, the\nwoman loses all control.
Even when her enemies are no\nmore than mangled hunks of\nflesh, she cannot stop.
Finally, the woman cradles her\nsister in her arms and gazes \nat her blood-stained face.
Their hair, once dark as night\nitself, was now pure white.\n
Yet the hairpin still glinted\nfrom atop the sister's head.
The woman was alone. Her fate\nwas sealed. And so she swore\na vow to her sister.
The fires of her revenge would\nrage until they consumed\nthe entire kingdom.
A mechanical soldier sleeps\namidst the detritus of a\ncastle storehouse.
Time has no meaning here.\nA minute is as an age.
Until the day he meets\nthe boy.
The exhausted boy can only\nmutter three simple words
"Let me...rest."
Seeking to help, the man\nbegins rooting around to\nprepare a makeshift bed.
As he continues to dig,\na discarded weapon\nsuddenly activates.
The man manages to assemble\na crude resting place from\nthe storehouse junk.
The boy wearily makes his way\nto the bed and manages a\nheartfelt thanks.
After studying the man for\na moment, he begins to ask\nhim questions.
The name the man gives is\nthat of the first model\nof clockwork soldiers.
"I was also a first once,"\nsays the boy. "First in line\nto the throne. But no more."
The man explains he was\nunable to carry out orders\nand discarded as defective.
The boy responds that as his\ndisease has grown worse, he,\ntoo, has been cast aside.
"You and I are much alike,"\nsays the boy with a sad smile.
Weary of talking, the boy\nfinally falls asleep.
The man simply sits, keeping\nthe boy's peaceful expression\nin the corner of his eye.
The cold room burdens the boy, \nand his condition worsens.
The man looks about and sees\nwhat appears to be a bottle \nof medicine.
But upon taking it in hand and looking\nat the label, he realizes it is actually\na weapon of poison gas...
The man continues to search for\nmedicine that might aid the boy.
It seems the storehouse\nexpands beyond the junk pile\npressed against the wall.
He retrieves a bottle from\nthe shelf and returns to the\nbed where the boy waits.
The boy looks at the man's\ngift and chuckles.
"Empty bottles won't cure me,\nI'm afraid." He says as the man\nstares at him blankly.
"Still..." says the boy.\nHe suddenly stands, as if a\nthought has come to mind.
The boy places a candle in the bottle,\nturning it into a small lamp.
He then begins to sing in\na small, quiet voice.
"By the power of his will\ndoes the hero draw his sword."
"To stop the mean advances\nof the darkness in the world."
"He will use this light to\nlead away the people\nfrom fear's horde."
It is the song of a hero\nwho challenges evil in\norder to save his people.
The lamp flickers warmly\nas the man thinks.
Thank you, he says finally.
Those words should not\nhave existed in the man,\nand yet somehow they did.
The boy's shocked stare slowly\nbecomes a smile bright enough\nto last a lifetime.
In the corner of a frigid room,\nthese two companions are\ncomforted by the same warmth.
Soldiers' voices drift in from outside.\nThe kingdom has once again declared war.
The boy looks at the man\nand opens his heart.
He once lacked the courage to\nstand against his father,\nand had stayed complicit.
But now he burns to stop the\nking and protect his people\nfrom the horrors of war.
The passion in his eyes is evident.
The man breaks through the door,\nand the boy follows after.
As a divine light shines behind\nhim, the king glares down at\nthe two interlopers.
In a bold voice, the boy\nshouts up at the king.
"By my name as the firstborn,\nI propose this war be ended!"
In that moment, he is just\nlike the hero of his song.
With a sneer, the king\nlooks to the clockwork\nsoldier and says...

The man freezes. But he cannot
disobey his master, for that
is how he was programmed.
With a shaking hand,\nhe readies his gun.
The boy stares straight at the \nman from the end of the barrel.
Unable to resist his orders, the man's\nfinger hovers over the trigger...
In a final, desperate move,\nthe man shuts down his own\nmotor circuits.
His finger lets go of the trigger,\nand he falls to his knees\nbefore the boy.
It is the first time he has\nresisted orders of his own \nvolition—all to save the boy.
With an animalistic cry, the king\nrises up before the pair.
The king's roar brings soldiers\nrunning as he demands they\ntear the traitors apart.
The man seizes the boy's hand\nand they begin to run from\nthe castle.
For the first time in his\nexistence, the man finally\nhas a will of his own.
The escapees arrive at the town \noutside the castle and find people\nin a panic over the impending war.
Somehow, the two manage\nto escape beyond the\nborders of the kingdom.
Looking back on their former\nhome, they each make an oath.
The boy swears to travel the\nnation as its prince and\nbring an end to the war.
While the man promises to\nguard the prince until his\ndying moment.
Together, they will sever\nthe marionette strings the\nkingdom has bound them to.
With determination in their hearts,\nthey take their first steps\ninto the future.
A man sits alone.
Though he speaks, the target\nof his words is unseen.
To this invisible listener,\nhe offers praise for a\ntask well-handled.
His eyes narrow. He hesitates.\nThen, his voice a rasp,\nhe murmers an instruction
"On to the next."
The target of his words is\nrevealed behind the scrim\nof a dividing wall.
She also sits alone.\nIn her hand rests a small\nscroll adorned with a face.

Slipping the scroll into the
folds of her robe, she stands
and makes her response:
"Understood."
Thick clouds hang low\nagainst an ominous sky.
The castle town bustles\nas people move to and fro.
A family traveling the road\ncatches her eye.
The child smiles brightly,\nher eyes sparkling.
The darkness of the woman's\nown life could never know\nsuch pleasant light.
Brushing aside her melancholy,\nshe makes to leave town.
A sudden glimpse of silver\ncatches the woman's eye as an\nassassin appears before her.
A thin razor of a smile\ncrosses her face;
she knows this is exactly\nwhere she belongs.
She claims the assassin's life\nbefore body can meet earth.
In the silence that follows,\nshe muses on her life.
She walks a path of blood;\na solitary path far from\nfamily or comfort.
Had she ever smiled as that\nchild did? Could she?
Such thoughts swirl in her mind\nas the woman considers a life\nshe knows she will never have.
The girl stirs from a thin sleep,\nher features weary as a woman\nthrice her years.
Her life is an unending blur\nof training that continues\nwithout mercy or pause.
Bones creak. Flesh stings.\nPain is her constant companion.
Yet she forces herself down\nthe hall all the same.
When she arrives at the garden,\na bellowing roar orders her forward.
"Coming," she replies in a\nvoice devoid of all feeling.
She readies an apology for her tardiness,\nknowing full well it will not be heard.
As suspected, the man cuts\noff her words and begins to\nberate her without pause.
"You WILL learn to honor punctuality, girl!"
"You are a tool of our master,\nand a tool is of no use if it is\nnot present when needed!"
Thus begins another day of\nthe girl's deadly training.
Her family has served their\nlord's clan for generations.
When the lord decides an enemy\nneeds to die, her family carries\nout the sentence.
Her path had been laid\nbefore she was even born.
The path of a trained killer.
There is no freedom for her;\nno thought of a different way.\nThe path simply was.
The woman does not bemoan her fate,\nfor she has never known another.
Yet when she thinks of the\nthings she will never have,\nshe feels a terrible sadness.
But she presses on regardless,\nleaving such distractions behind.
At some point, she realizes\nthat rain has begun to fall.
Through the droplets,\nshe spies a castle with a\ndark and enigmatic aura.
Soon she finds a lone guard\nstanding before a gate.
Moving without sound,\nshe loosens her sword.
With death delivered, she sheathes\nher blade and presses on.
The woman moves ever deeper\ninto the castle in search of\nher target.
Her mission is to kill the son\nof an enemy lord and halt\nhis possible succession.
The enemy army values blood.\nIf the successor were to die,\nchaos will inevitably follow.
Slaying the son will create confusion,\ngiving her own lord an opening for attack.
She passes through the corridors\nand moves toward a reception room.
Outside, the rain falls in\nendless gray sheets.
A child sits alone, his frame made\nsmaller by the size of the room.
She recognizes the boy's\nface from her scroll.
Without a word, she draws her sword\nand points the tip at the child's throat.
Yet he simply stares at the cold steel,\nmaking no move to escape.
As the woman studies the child's\nhaggard face, she realizes something.
This is no son of a lord, but instead\na girl frocked in boy's clothing.
The woman asks her target why this is.
As if a dam has burst, the girl suddenly\nlets fly with a torrent of grievance.
"I wish this house and this\nentire nation would fall."
The girl begins to tell her tale.\n"I am naught but a puppet who\ndances at my father's tune."
"I'm no child to him—\nmerely a tool to be used."
"I even denied my own heart and took\nfalse gender in order to fulfill my role."
"And as this house's tool,\nI live only to be killed."
"So please, just bring this to pass.\nEnd me."
The girl's eyes turn to rest\non the woman.
This is who I used to be.
Set to walk a path before\nI had even drawn breath.
The woman's sword waivers.\nHer hand hesitates.
Outside, the rain falls as if it was trying\nto blot out the very earth itself.
And yet somehow it feels quiet...
The only sound is the rain.
A long moment passes.
The woman sheaths her blade.
She then asks the bewildered girl,
"Did you mean it when you said\nyou wish your house would fall?"
Shaking, the girl nods.
The woman responds,
"Understood."
Suddenly, the sounds of an\narmy clattering into place\nemerge behind them.
A score of soldiers bursts\ninto the reception room.
The woman's face is the\nvery picture of composure.
"Come then," she whispers.
The girl runs over and\ntakes her hand.
Why had she done this?
The sound of the rain\nbegins to fade.
People cannot choose the\nstation of their birth.
One can scarcely even choose\ntheir own manner of death in\nthis violent, fleeting world.
But perhaps...one can choose\nto let another live.
I was a tool of my house who\ncarried out her role.
My hands are stained with\nsins beyond counting.
I doubt this will absolve\nme of my actions...
but it might make a nice gift\nto bring with me into hell.
She can no longer hear the rain.
Tears roll down the girl's cheeks.
And on the woman's face...
is something almost like a smile.
A man makes his way along a\nmountain path buried in snow.
There is no movement. No sound.\nOnly a perfect wall of unbroken white.
His breath comes out in a\nset of steady white puffs.
Before long, the sun begins to set.
Yet the man's pace does not falter.
A rift in the ground blocks his way.
The crevice is so deep he cannot\nsee the bottom.
The man produces his trusty hand-axe\nfrom within a deep pocket.
The man produces his trusty hand-axe\nfrom within a deep pocket.
The path beneath him precarious,\nmaintaining his balance is a matter\nof life and death.
The path beneath him precarious,\nmaintaining his balance is a matter\nof life and death.
Once he moves past the danger,\nhe again makes for the peak.
Before he realizes it,\nthe land around him is\nbathed in moonlight.
The man knows the mountain\nis more dangerous at night.
Yet it still holds for him\na kind of wondrous charm.
He does not fear this place;\ninstead he trusts in his\nstrength and experience.
Suddenly, the steely glint of animal eyes\nglimmer all around him.
The man, remaining calm,\nconfronts a pack of wolves.
Don't run. Don't turn away.\nDon't look them in the eye.
The final roar sounds.
After fending off the wolves,\nthe man renews his trek.
No person has ever reached the summit\nof the mountain he now climbs.
Yet he does not fear, for he has conquered\nmany peaks long thought impossible.
He forever seeks the line\nbetween life and death within\nthe harshest environments.
This pursuit is his entire\nreason for living.
A terrible blizzard rages across\nthe snowy mountain.
The merciless wind and snow\ncause his steps to slow.
Suddenly, his weary eyes\nglimpse a rocky shelter just\nbig enough for a single man.
As he catches his breath,\nhe recalls the letter tucked\naway inside his pocket.
His daughter had given it to him\nbefore he started his climb.
He fishes in his deep pocket once more\nand produces a handmade charm.
The oddly shaped decoration\nseems to warm the man from\nsomewhere deep inside.
Having risen to his feet,\nthe man's legs are filled\nwith renewed strength.
Halfway up the mountain,\nhe comes across a frozen lake.
The corpse on the ground wears\nthe attire of a mountaineer.
And its regrets suddenly take form\nas a ghost and spread\na terrible darkness.
He sees a note on the ground\nnext to the body.
It is an apology to the\nmountaineer's family.
It spells out his regret at\never attempting his climb.
The note is written in a\ncramped, unsteady hand.
Perhaps it is due to cold.\nPerhaps to grief.
A tremendous cliff looms\nbefore the man.
If he can conquer this,\nthe mountain will be his.
Balling up his numb fists, he whispers\nencouraging words to himself.
Though his frozen body threatens to rebel,\nhe finally reaches the summit.
And though the mountain has\nsupposedly never been climbed,\nhe finds a ruined shrine.
Intrigued by this mysterious sight,\nthe man ventures onward.
How long has it been here?\nHow old is it?
It has waited here for ages;\na thing outside of time.
He feels his adventurer's\nblood begin to stir.
Careful examination reveals that\nthe structure still has its roof.
When he enters the shrine,\n he finds something impossible:\nhis wife.
Looking closer, he realizes it is the corpse\nof another pregnant woman.
The corpse grips a clunky\ngood-luck charm in one\nfrozen hand.
It looks just like the one\nhis own daughter gave him.
The man is gripped by a desire to descend the mountain\nand return to his family.
Why did you leave us?
The baby is coming.
He rubs his eyes and looks\nat the woman again.
What he thought was his wife\nis in fact the frozen corpse\nof another pregnant woman.
The corpse grips a clunky\ngood-luck charm in one\nfrozen hand.
It looks just like the one\nhis own daughter gave him.
Enough. Time to go.
The hallucination solidifies his resolution\nto return home to his family.
A lonely house illuminated by a dim light\nsits in a forest of deep snow.
Suddenly, a furious knocking\nbatters at the door.
The door flies open to reveal\nan aberration that looks\nstrangely like the girl's father.
It seems the knock was but\na trick of the wind.
The woman presses against her swollen\nstomach and collapses to the ground.
New life is about to be\nbrought into the world.
The man is in darkness.
Pain courses through a body that struggles\nto follow the orders of its mind.
With each movement he makes,\nhis arms and legs grow heavier.
As the cold sets into his bones,\nhe comes to a sudden realization
Ah, I see...\nI...am already gone.
He fumbles frozen, unfeeling fingers\ninto his pocket once last time.
The charm from his daughter still\nretains a tiny coal of warmth.
With the sensation of his\nfamily at his fingertips,\nhe slowly closes his eyes.
A shopping mall.\nA common sight.
A family.\nA common sight.
Though seemingly mundane,\nthese are truly the most\nblessed and rare of days.
Thankful for the gift of routine,\nthe couple enjoys their ordinary lives.
The ground begins to tremble\nas screams erupt from outside\nthe shopping mall.
There, poised to attack their child,\nis what appears to be a massive flower.
A nightmare—one that repeats\ntime and again and leads back\nto a reality of despair.
His wife's eyes are dim pools\nfilled with resignation,\nmisery, and loss.
But they have sworn to enact\nrevenge on the Flowers.
It is the only thing that\nkeeps him moving forward.
The announcement comes at\nthe same time every day.
It notifies those in\nwhite of mealtimes.
As ever, the man dutifully\nmakes for the feeding hall.
The white marks him—and all\nothers who wear it—as people\nwithout freedom.
The rules must be obeyed.
As the woman tries to escape,\nthe hue in her eyes changes\nfrom unease to madness.
The actions and thoughts of\nthe prisoners in white are\nnot theirs to control.
An alarm echoes through the\nfacility announcing the\narrival of the Flowers.
The same unearthly beings that\nkilled their son and tore their\nonce-happy family apart.
They are the gravest threat\nthe world has ever known.
The prisoners are transported\nin cramped, stuffy containers\nas if they were mere cargo.
The Flower threat has forced\nthe government to conscript\ncivilians as soldiers.
The man and his wife are no\nexception to this rule.

The prisoners charge the
massive Flowers, intent
on eliminating them.
Another day. Another battle.\nA common sight.
But this time, they discover a\nlarger, more sinister Flower\nthan any they have yet seen.
Just when all hope seems lost,\ntheir allies come to the rescue.
They cannot even thank them\nby name, for they are known\nonly by letters and numbers.
But somehow, they have a\ngreater sense of solidarity\nthan when they had been free.
...Or so they had thought.
Their fellow prisoners remain\nfrozen in place like a people\nsomehow out of time.
The man and his wife look on,\ntrying desperately to make\nsense of what is happening.
Suddenly the prisoners begin\nto march, their footsteps\nall in perfect synch.
The man and his wife behold\na sight most uncanny.
Without a word, the prisoners\nbegin to throw themselves into\nthe depths below.
The man and his wife prove no\nmatch for their fellows.
The officer begins to tell them about\nthe strategy they use to fight the Flowers.
Though strategy is a\nkind word for it.
"Experiment" is far\nmore appropriate.
Data from the prisoners'\nbattles with the Flowers\nis recorded and analyzed.
Any found wanting—or any who\nexhibit a sense of self—are\ndetermined to be "defective."
...And are disposed of by the organization.
When the man awakens,\nhe sees his fellow prisoners.
He is the only survivor.
This is unforgiveable.\nUnforgiveable.\nUnforgiveable.
In the depths of the earth,\nthe man emits a roar of pain.
The woman wakes in a dark\nand crumbling place.
Pain races through her body.
She thought she would die\nwhen she saved her husband\nfrom the commander.
Yet she is still alive.\nBut...why?
Trying to make sense of her\npiecemeal memories,\nshe starts walking.
Her location is a mystery.
Eventually, she discovers people\nclad in the same clothing as her\ncollapsed among some rubble.
Suddenly, her husband appears,\nalong with some of her old\nfellow prisoners.
The joy they feel in this moment\nis beyond all measure.
The woman is brought to a\nbase for former prisoners.
Pain shoots through her head.\nShe can't remember anything after\nbeing separated from her husband.
As part of their resistance to the organization,\nthe defectives had been plotting ways to free\ntheir fellow prisoners
The organization had ordered\nthe prisoners to hunt down\nthe escaped defectives.
Despite the organization's orders,\nthe defective prisoners have a plan
During the next Flower attack,\nthey will sneak into the\norganization's HQ.
Once there, they will free\nall the remaining prisoners\nin one fell swoop.
Acting as an advance scout\nteam, the man and his wife\nenter the HQ.
They had spent so much of\ntheir lives here...
But this was the first time\nthey were able to move about\nof their own volition.
They had trained here for\ndays without end.
All so they could exact\nrevenge on the Flowers\nthat stole their son.
Everyone here was the same.\nThey all had a reason to\nwant the Flowers dead.
But in that case, why were\nthey shackled by so many\nunnecessary rules?
In all of their time here,\nthey had never stopped to\nwonder why this was.
This is the first time either\nof them has ever set foot in\nthe incubation room.
Sleeping prisoners float\npeacefully inside liquid-\nfilled capsules.
Their pain. Their desire for\nrevenge. It all stemmed from\ntheir son's death.
The commander begins\nto tell his tale.
Humans—true humans—\nno longer exist.
You prisoners are nothing\nbut clones. Pale imitations.
And in order to give you a\nreason to fight, we implanted\nyou with...memories.
memory
my memories
remember
FALSE
kill the enemy
kill your loved one
As she clings to her fading\nwill, she makes a decision.
She remembers a process the\ncommander installed in her\nthe first time she died.
A setting that deletes even her\nfalse self, making her a mindless\nweapon of carnage.
Sacrificial death confirmed.\nCause: Marital bonds.
Data saved as reference for\nfuture clone development.
Test concluded.
The woman tells her husband\nshe will soon lose herself.
She remembers a process the\ncommander installed in her\nthe first time she died
A setting that deletes even her\nfalse self, making her a mindless\nweapon of carnage.
Mutual death confirmed.\nCause: Marital bonds.
The boy lives in a country\nthat has been beset by a\nlong, drawn-out war.
Each night, gunfire erupts\nand stirs his anxiety.
Frightened, he heads to the living\nroom to be with his parents.
His mother's smile always\nmanages to cheer the boy up.
Though he is a coward at\nheart, he says this for the\nsake of his beloved mother,
"One day I'll be a soldier\nand keep you safe, Mom."
His mother breaks into a wide,\nhappy smile at his words.
Suddenly, there is a loud\nnoise from the entrance\nto the home.
His parents scream for a long,\nagonizing moment.
And then they fall silent.
The enemy soldier overlooks\nthe boy and leaves.
He nervously makes his way to\nthe corridor where he'd heard\nhis parents' terrible screams.
He finds the corpses of his parents\ncooling on the floor.
He inches closer and examines\nthe sword that is impaled in\nhis father's still form.
It is decorated with a\ndistinctive emblem.
The boy crumples to the floor\nand begins to sob as shame at\nhis weakness overwhelms him.
Even now, the thought of the\nenemy he saw from the closet\nmakes him go weak in the knees.
He is a coward. A craven.\nA sniveling child who had\nbeen unable to act.
Years pass. The boy that lost his parents\nhas become a soldier.
He did so for one reason:\nTo find the man who ruined\nhis life and kill him.
Once afraid, the boy is now\npossessed by naught but pure,\nunyielding vengeance.
The other troops often single\nout the unsociable boy.
The boy stares back at\nthe soldier before him.
The coward he once was is\nnow a distant stranger.
Their captain steps in\nto stop the quarrel.
But rather than look at him,\nthe boy turns away.
Though a captain, the man is\nrather soft and weak-willed.
When the boy looks at him,\nit is like looking at the\ncoward he once was.
Turning his back on his caring\ncaptain, the boy departs.
The next day, the soldiers are briefed\non their upcoming operation.
Each one of them receives\na set of materials.
When the boy looks at the\ndocuments, a terrifying smile\nslowly emerges on his face.
For on the first page is the\nsame emblem that was on the\nsword all those years ago.
His sworn enemy was close now.\nSo very close.
The boy feels his blood begin\nto boil as he considers this...
Then he slowly makes his\nway to the captain.
There is a man among our foes—\nthe same man who killed my parents.
I owe this man; the debt must\nbe paid. Put me in the front\nline so I may take his life!
Enraged, the boy draws his\nweapon and moves to attack\nhis own captain.
Though the other man quakes\nin fear, he does not rescind\nfrom his previous order.
The boy hurls abuse at the\ntimid man as he sheathes his\nweapon and departs.
As the other soldiers sleep,\nthe boy stirs.
If he can't get permission,\nhe will simply act alone.
It is the same burly soldier\nwho always tries to fight him.
The boy lies.
Though this soldier usually irritates\nhim, today he pays him no mind.
Instead, he bends all his thought on\nthe man who took his parents from him.
He has killed him over and over\nin his imagination, but now...
The boy infiltrates the enemy\ncamp just before daybreak.
The rows of tents are silent\nin the shadow of dawn.
A small fire burns in a tent deep\nwithin the camp, and he senses\nthe presence of an enemy.
It's him.
As hatred flares inside him,\nthe boy strikes at the man\nwith all of his might.
The enemy captain looks the\nboy square in the eyes.
And then, his voice unsteady,\nhe murmurs something.
He pauses, coughs up a gout\nof blood, and tries again
Lying on death's door, the enemy\nsoldier says his piece.
He tells the boy the truth\nof that fateful night
He was not a random soldier,\nbut the boy's own father.
The couple were not his\nparents, but brigands who\nstole him from the cradle.
With a trembling hand, the man\nhands the boy a small notebook\nbefore breathing his last.
In it, he learns his home\ncountry ran a kidnapping\nscheme targeting infants.
Glued within the pages are\nmultiple pictures of the\ncouple who raised him.
His parents are a sin; his\nlife a sham. He has devoted\nhis existence to... nothing.
The battlefield lies in a\ncold, hollow silence as the\nsun slowly begins to rise...
A timid military captain\nlives in a nation where\nwars rage without pause.
His frequent retreats have\ncaused his men to nickname\nhim "Captain Craven."
This morning, he walks around\nthe base and orders his men\nto prepare for combat.
Daily, the captain finds\nhimself mediating quarrels\namong his hot-blooded men.
And yet, he never treats\nthem as anything other than\nhis trusted fellows.
After finishing his rounds,\nthe captain restores a\ntemporary discipline.
Earlier, a young boy had\nvolunteered for combat so\nhe could avenge his parents.
But concerned for the boy's well-being,\nthe captain had turned down his proposal.
Dark clouds gather as they\nready for combat, matching\nthe captain's mood...
With several units in tow,\nthe captain and his army\nmarch for the enemy camp.
Their goal is to annihilate\nthe enemy—and, if possible,\nlocate the missing boy.
As always, his orders are\ncautious; the safety of his\nmen his overriding concern.
The captain and his men soon\narrive at the enemy camp.
As planned, another team\ninitiates a feint attack\nto draw attention.
Cautiously, the captain moves\ninto the enemy camp.
After a moment, he locates\nthe bloodied corpse of the\nenemy commander.
A familiar blade protrudes\nfrom a hole in his chest.
He knows this sword—the\nmissing boy had pointed it\nat him the night before.
But the boy is nowhere to be\nfound, and the captain knows\nhe is in grave danger.
He stares at the scene\nbefore him and whispers,
"Have I failed again?"
Years ago, the cowardly captain\nwas but a meager foot soldier.
He possessed the arrogance of\nyouth, and often butted heads\nwith his commanders.
After one intense battle,\nhe found himself searching\nfor any surviving comrades.
The first corpse he found was\na senior officer who used to\nbark orders at him.
The next, a fellow soldier\nwith whom he often fought.
He had done this—he had\nignored orders and brought\nhis squadron to ruin.
As he cursed himself, he found a\nsurvivor: an officer whom he\nhad often mocked.
The officer closed his eyes,\nlet out a final, blackened\nbreath, and died.
This is all your fault!
You're always so selfish!
You killed all of us!
"I'm glad you survived..."
Those words would haunt the\nyoung soldier for the rest\nof his days.
Eight years later...
Though fearful at the thought of\nlosing his men, he continued on\nas a soldier.
He now attempts to atone for\nhis mistakes by ensuring\nno one else has to die.
Finally, he finds the boy\nwounded and hiding behind\na bit of cover.
His heart skips a beat;\nit is like seeing himself\nsome eight years ago.
I will do whatever\nI must to save him.
With that thought in mind,\nthe captain reaches down\nfor the injured boy.
The captain hauls the boy onto his\nback and starts making his\nreturn to the base.
Despite the danger, he\ncontinues issuing orders\nremotely as they travel.
He will not rest until every\nlast one of his men is seen\nsafely out of harm's way.
Suddenly, the boy on his\nback emits a small groan.
In a thin voice, he admits\nhis error and apologizes for\nhis selfish actions.
Though he managed to save\nthe boy, the captain has taken\na most grievous wound.
If another enemy were to find\nthem now, he likely will not\nbe able to fend them off.
Pushing aside the pain,\nhe continues his march.
It's all your fault!
I won't repeat my mistakes!
I'm a different man now!
Your arrogance is\nkilling our allies!
No one will die on my watch!
I'll find a way to save\nevery last man!
And if that comes at the cost\nof my own life...so be it.
The captain is reaching\nhis physical limit.
He will leave no man behind. He will\nlet no man die. It is a naive belief,\nyet it keeps him going.
Soon, another enemy force\nappears to bar their way.
The captain stares them down,\nplacing his own body between\nthem and his young charge.
Suddenly, the rest of\nhis squad appears.
Breaths are held. Fingers lie\ntense on weapons. One false\nmove will mean a slaughter.
Finally, after a long moment,\nthe enemy retreats.
The squad had come to\ntheir captain's aid.
Miraculously, they have\nall survived the mission.
With his eyelids heavy,\nhe murmurs to the boy,
"I'm glad you survived..."
The squad is overjoyed to see their captain alive.
His men—the family\nhe built at the cost of his\npride—have saved him.
They pick the boy up and\nbegin to tease him, saying\nhe's lucky to be alive.
The boy responds with a dry\nsmile—the first time any of\nthem remember him doing so.
The sound of their laughter\nrings out happily across the\ndesolate battlefield...
The girl awakens to find\nher mind a perfect blank.
She knows not where she is.\nWho she is.
She does not even know if these\nare questions worth asking.
She hears a voice; almost a faint scream.
I must go there.
She knows not where "there" is,\nyet she begins to walk all the same.
She moves down the corridor\nas if the voice drives her.
Along the path, she finds a large\ncrystal in the shape of a person.
Her hand, acting of its own\naccord, reaches out for the\nstrange object.
Images flood her mind;\nmemories left within\nthe crystal.
And through these memories,\nshe suddenly understands.
This crystal is the corpse of\na girl—a girl of the same\ntype as herself.
We were created\nto be weapons.
An eerie sound spills from\nthe top of her head.
An eerie sound slithers from\nthe soles of her feet.
A white aberration appears,\nits state of matter undefined.
Sensing its hostility,\nthe girl's eyes turn red.
The girl dispatches\nthe white creature.
She fought with such agility,\nit seems impossible to think\nshe is so newly awakened.
Her composure flawless, the\ngirl continues down the hall.
The voice in her head drives\nher on relentlessly.
She finds herself in a\ndarkness devoid of life.
Yet she continues on\nin search of answers.
The girl traverses a corridor\nfilled with rubble.
A fight happened here.
She spies a faint light\nfiltering in through the\ncollapsed ceiling.
The girl climbs the rubble,\nseeking the light's source.
Having climbed the wreckage, she\nspies row upon row of living plants.
The light spilling into the\ncorridor below had been for\ntheir benefit.
Enraptured at the sight of the\nplants, the girl is suddenly\nbeset by a terrible vertigo.
Her vision spins.\nHer mind reels.
But she somehow manages to\nbrush these feelings aside\nand continue her journey.
An aberration once again appears\nto block her progress.
She stares down her enemy\nwith red eyes and utterly\nflawless composure.
The white phantom evaporates\nlike so much mist.
These corpses were weapons\nlike her—she might have even\ncalled them her "sisters."
She holds up a hand up to the\ncrystal and closes her eyes.
A torrent of images race\nforth and swallow the\ngirl's consciousness.
They are memories.\nAnd they are horrible.
Girls—her sisters—overrun\nby a horde of aberrations.
Their pain and agony\nfloods though her mind.
The white aberrations brought\nruin to the facility.
Having inherited the memories,\nthe girl moves on.
She must learn more.\nShe must appease the\nvoice in her head.
I must go there.
The voice in her head leads\nthe way once more.
Suddenly, a vibration strong\nenough to shake the floor.\nSomething had roared.
The sound came from the\nspace just ahead of her.
A glowing terminal stands\nbefore a dividing wall.
She knows what this is.
More precisely, her inherited\nmemories know it.
They know she needs a key in\norder to make this device\nopen the wall beyond.
She begins to search.
For reasons beyond knowing,\na monster appears before\nthe girl a third time.
She grips her spear tightly,\nred eyes shining out from\nher impassive face.
Stale air spills out from\nthe other side of the door.\nIt is an elevator.
Hearing it creak to life,\nthe girl closes her eyes.
Illuminated in crimson,\nthe room is enveloped\nin an odd atmosphere.
The device in the middle\nof the room is filled\nwith shimmering liquid.
Suspended in the flux\nis an oddly-shaped spear.
The memory she receives\nis of the beginning.
The first of the living-\nweapon sisters.
The eldest of her sisters\nhad lost control and birthed\nthe aberrations.
This was the cause of the\nfacility's destruction.
She sees a card beside\na small piece of paper.
She knows it is the key that\nopens the wall, and takes it.
The memories tie together.\nShe feels her sisters'\nemotions race through her.
Enduring the flood of\nimages, she presses on.
She now understands that her\neldest sister still suffers.
She continues to move down\nthe long and winding path.
She knows the answers she\nseeks are waiting for her\nsomewhere up ahead...
And that her sister\nis waiting as well.
When she enters the room,\nshe spies a massive something\nat its heart.
It is the leader of the aberrations.
But it is more that that.
It is also her older sister;\nthe one who lost control.
Her eldest sister spreads her\nwhite wings and howls in a\nferocious voice.
This cry of enmity toward\nthe world shakes the entire\nfacility to its foundation.
A death rattle hisses\nfrom her massive throat.
Her body falls to the floor.
The sisters' duel is over.
As her elder transforms into\ncrystal, the girl slowly\nbrings up her hand.
Her sister's memories race\nthrough her like a tide.
She sees it, then:\nThe place she must go.
It was a precious place to\nthe older sister when she\nwas still human.
Plucking her sister's sword\nfrom the floor, she whispers,
"Leave all to me."
She makes her way to the\noutside world, toward the\nplace of memory.
Though she sets off from\nher place of birth alone...
She carries the hopes and\ndreams of all her sisters\non her shoulders.
